channel.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
channel.description:
You may use your preferred programming language.
Write an algorithm that takes an integer array as input and outputs an array of arrays. Each array in the output array should represent a sequence of even integers in the input array. The output array has to be sorted (sorted sequences) in descending order, the value of a sequence is the sum of it's elements.
Input data: [code] { 1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000 } [/code]
Expected output: [code] 10000 0 2000 10 200 4 8 2 4 10 8 6 2 [/code]
I'll post my C++ solution later.
[b]EDIT:[/b] http://pastie.org/private/vgqqmw6mrpvxjq1zpc2xw

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences

[quote=“imthenull, post:23, topic:433361”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=536080.msg4020450#msg4020450 date=1339981301]

[1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000].chunk{|i| i.even? || nil}.sort_by{|x| x[1].inject(:+)}.reverse_each{|m| p m[1]}
[/quote]
nice :)[/quote]s/nice/horrific but cool/

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Hackish (fast) Java solution:

[code=java]import java.util.Collection;
import java.util.Deque;
import java.util.ArrayDeque;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.IdentityHashMap;
import java.util.Set;
import java.util.TreeSet;
import java.util.Comparator;
import java.util.Random;

class SequenceExtractor {

static Collection<Deque<Integer>> extract(int[] input) {
    final int n = input.length;

    Set<Deque<Integer>> seqs = new TreeSet<Deque<Integer>>(new Comparator<Deque<Integer>>() {
        private final Map<Deque<Integer>, Integer> tab = new IdentityHashMap<Deque<Integer>, Integer>(n);

        private int sum(Deque<Integer> seq) {
            Integer lookup = tab.get(seq);
            if (lookup == null) {
                int sum = 0;
                for (Integer val : seq) {
                    sum += val.intValue();
                }

                tab.put(seq, sum);
                return sum;
            } else {
                return lookup.intValue();
            }
        }

        public int compare(Deque<Integer> u, Deque<Integer> v) {
            return sum(v) - sum(u);
        }
    });

    int cur = 0;
    boolean state = false;
    Deque<Integer> seq = null;
    while (cur < n) {
        int in = input[cur++];

        if ((in & 1) == 0) {
            if (!state) {
                state = true;
                seq = new ArrayDeque<Integer>(n);
            }
            seq.add(in);
        } else if (state) {
            state = false;
            seqs.add(seq);
        }
    }

    if (state) {
        seqs.add(seq);
    }

    return seqs;
}

static void print(Collection<Deque<Integer>> results) {
    for (Deque<Integer> seq : results) {
        StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
        for (Integer val : seq) { 
            builder.append(val + " ");
        }
        System.out.print(builder.append("\n").toString());
    }
}

public static void main(String[] argv) {
    final int[] input = new int[] { 1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000 };
    final int n = input.length;

    final Random rand = new Random();
    long dur = 0;

    Collection<Deque<Integer>> rsl;

    for (int i = 0; i < 10000; ++i) {
        input[rand.nextInt(n)]++;

        long start = System.nanoTime();

        rsl = extract(input);

        dur += (System.nanoTime() - start);

        print(rsl);
    }

    System.out.printf("avg period per extraction: %dns%n", dur / 10000);
}

}[/code]

Using java -server:

C:\dev>java -server -version java version "1.7.0_03" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_03-b05) Java HotSpot(TM) Server VM (build 22.1-b02, mixed mode)

Average periods all in the range 6700-7000ns.

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:12, topic:433361”][code=Javascript]
var input = [1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000],
output = [];

function sumArray(which) {
var sum = 0;

for(var i = 0; i < which.length; i++) {
    sum += which[i];
}

return sum;

}

function main() {
var length = input.length,
sequence = [];

function appendSequence() {
    output.push(sequence);
    sequence = [];
}

for(var i = 0; i < length; i++) {
    var num = input[i];
                        
    if(num % 2 === 0) {
        sequence.push(num);
        
        if(i === input.length - 1) {
            appendSequence();
        }
    } else {
        if (sequence.length > 0) {
            appendSequence();
        }
    }
}

output = output.sort(function(a, b) {
    return sumArray(a) < sumArray(b);
});

console.log(output);

}

main();
[/code]

Somebody please post more programming challenges :([/quote]feb 19th -> jun 11th… ok that’s definitely not a gravedig

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

var input = [1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000],
    output = [];

function sumArray(which) {
    var sum = 0;
    
    for(var i = 0; i < which.length; i++) {
        sum += which[i];
    }
    
    return sum;
}
            
function main() {
    var length = input.length,
        sequence = [];
        
    function appendSequence() {
        output.push(sequence);
        sequence = [];
    }
    
    for(var i = 0; i < length; i++) {
        var num = input[i];
                            
        if(num % 2 === 0) {
            sequence.push(num);
            
            if(i === input.length - 1) {
                appendSequence();
            }
        } else {
            if (sequence.length > 0) {
                appendSequence();
            }
        }
    }
    
    output = output.sort(function(a, b) {
        return sumArray(a) < sumArray(b);
    });
    
    console.log(output);
}

main();

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote="(Anthony), post:8, topic:433361"][code=haskell]import Data.List

{-

  • Write an algorithm that takes an integer array as input and outputs an array of arrays.
  • Each array in the output array should represent a sequence of even integers in the input array.
  • The output array has to be sorted (sorted sequences) in descending order, the value of a sequence is the sum of it’s elements.
    -}

build :: Integral a => [a] -> [[a]]
build l = let res = (takeWhile even . dropWhile odd) l in
if null (tail res) then [res]
else res : build (tail l \ res)

sortlist :: Integral a => [[a]] -> [[a]]
sortlist = sortBy $ \a b -> compare (sum b) (sum a)

extract :: Integral a => [a] -> [[a]]
extract = sortlist . build

main :: IO ()
main = mapM_ print $ extract [1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000][/code]

all credits to _s[/quote]
what language is that?

Read full topic

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @sw0o0sh sw0o0sh
item.description:
@sw0o0sh wrote:

<?php

	class doSomethingSoSweet {
	
		var $initArray = array(1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000);
		var $ruleBlock;
		var $tmp;
	
		public function __construct() {
		
			$this->setRuleBlock();
			$this->decypherRuleBlock();
			$this->generateChildren();
			
		}
		
		public function setRuleBlock() {
			$this->ruleBlock = array(
				'3MDtpOjExO2k6MTtpOjEyO2k6Mjtp',
				'Y0To1OntpOjA7YToxOntpOjA7aTox',
				'e27k6MDtpOjg7aToxO2k6Mjt9fQ==',
				'aTo5wO2k6MjtpOjE7aTozO2k6Mjtp',
				'OTt91aToxO2E6Mjp7aTowO2k6MTY7',
				'OjExO62k6MztpOjU7fWk6NDthOjI6',
				'aToxO22k6MTc7fWk6MjthOjQ6e2k6',
				'OjM7aTo4zO2k6NTt9aTozO2E6NDp7',
			);
			
		}
		
		public function decypherRuleBlock() {
		
			for($i = 0; $i < count($this->ruleBlock); $i++) 
				$this->tmp[substr($this->ruleBlock[$i], $i, 1)] = substr_replace($this->ruleBlock[$i], '', $i, 1);
			ksort($this->tmp);
			
		}
		
		public function generateChildren() {
		
			foreach(unserialize(base64_decode(implode($this->tmp, ''))) as $i => $v) {
				foreach($v as $num) {
					$tmp[$i] = isset($tmp[$i]) ? $tmp[$i] : null;
					$tmp[$i][] = $this->initArray[$num];
				}
			}
			$this->tmp = $tmp;
				
		}
	
	}
	
	$initSweetness = new doSomethingSoSweet();
	print_r($initSweetness->tmp);
	
?>

shwoopty poopies

Array
(
    [0] => Array
        (
            [0] => 10000
        )

    [1] => Array
        (
            [0] => 0
            [1] => 2000
        )

    [2] => Array
        (
            [0] => 10
            [1] => 200
            [2] => 4
            [3] => 8
        )

    [3] => Array
        (
            [0] => 2
            [1] => 4
            [2] => 10
            [3] => 8
        )

    [4] => Array
        (
            [0] => 6
            [1] => 2
        )

)

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

my scala solution, in a super unreadable state… lol

[code]import scala.Array.canBuildFrom
import scala.collection.immutable.List
import scala.runtime.ScalaRunTime.stringOf

object main {

def main(args: Array[String]) = {
val array = List[Int](1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000)
x(array).foreach { a =>
println(stringOf(a))
}
}

def x(list: List[Int]) = {
var z = ArrayArray[Int]
var b = ArrayInt
list.foreach { i =>
if (i % 2 == 0) {
b = b ++ ArrayInt
} else {
if (b.size > 0) z = z ++ ArrayArray[Int]
b = ArrayInt
}
}
if (b.size > 0) z = z ++ ArrayArray[Int];

var v = List[Array[Int]]()
z.foreach { j =>
  var s = 0
  j.foreach { k => 
    s += k
  }
  if (v.size == 0) v = List[Array[Int]](j) ++ v
  
  v.foreach { m =>
    var q = 0
    m.foreach { r =>
      q += r
    }
    if (s > q) v = List[Array[Int]](j) ++ v else v = v ++ List[Array[Int]](j)
  }
}
g(v)

}

def g(d:List[Array[Int]]): List[Array[Int]] = {
if (d.isEmpty)
d
else
d.head :: g(for (x <- d.tail if x != d.head) yield x)
}

}[/code]

output:Array(10000) Array(0, 2000) Array(10, 200, 4, 8) Array(2, 4, 10, 8) Array(6, 2)

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

'''
    Author:
        t4

    Problem:
        Write an algorithm that takes an integer array as input and outputs an array of arrays. 
        Each array in the output array should represent a sequence of even integers in the input array.
        The output array has to be sorted (sorted sequences) in descending order based on the value of a
        sequence's sum of elements.
'''

'''
    Uses the quick sort algorithm to sort an array of data
'''
def quickSort(array, less):
    if len(array) < 2:
        return array
    pivot = array[(0 + len(array) - 1) / 2]
    array.remove(pivot)
    lesser = []
    greater = []
    for element in array:
        if less(element, pivot):
            lesser += [element]
        else:
            greater += [element]
    return quickSort(lesser, less) + [pivot] + quickSort(greater, less)

'''
    Is a given n even
'''
def isEven(n):
    return (n % 2) == 0

'''
    Compares sums of arrays
'''
def lessThanOrEqual(x, y):
    return sum(x) <= sum(y)

'''
    Filters certain elements of an array based on a given filter
'''
def filtr(array, filter_):
    filteredArray = []
    for element in array:
        if(filter_(element)):
            filteredArray += [element]
    return filteredArray

'''
    Sorts the given array into an output that solves the problem
'''
def problemSort(evenList):
    sequences = []
    sequence = []
    for n in evenList:
        sequence += [n]
        ptr = evenList.index(n)
        if len(sequence) > 1 and not sequence in sequences:
            sequences += [sequence]
            sequence = []
    sequences = quickSort(sequences, lessThanOrEqual)
    sequences += [[evenList[len(evenList) - 1]]]
    return sequences

'''
    Main method
'''
def main():
    list = [ 1, 3, 2, 4, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 2, 5, 10, 200, 4, 8, 3, 0, 2000, 1, 10000 ]
    evenList = filtr(list, isEven)
    print evenList
    print problemSort(evenList)
    return 0;

main();

Result:

[[2, 4], [6, 2], [4, 8], [10, 8], [10, 200], [0, 2000], [10000]]

w/e, still slight confused on the specifics of the instructions, but my output is a strictly increasing set of elements based on the sub-elements of each element’s sum.

OP explained on IRC - will fix later if i have time.
protip: don’t remove the odd elements first like it did

Read full topic

item.title: [Programming challenge] Extracting sequences
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

This is my C# version, employing LINQ <3

Edit:

[code=csharp]using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;

namespace ExtractingSequences {
class Program {
static void Main(string[] args) {
string input = Console.ReadLine() ?? “”;

        if (input.Equals("")) {
            Console.WriteLine("USAGE: num1,num2,...,num3");
            Console.ReadKey();
            Environment.Exit(1);
        }
        string[] numbers = input.Split(',');

        List<int> sequence = new List<int>();
        List<List<int>> sequences = new List<List<int>>();

        foreach (int n in numbers.Select(Int32.Parse)) {
            if (n % 2 == 0) {
                sequence.Add(n);
            } else if (sequence.Count > 0 && !sequences.Contains(sequence)) {
                sequences.Add(sequence);
                sequence = new List<int>();
            }
        }

        if (sequence.Count > 0) {
            sequences.Add(sequence);
        }

        sequences.Sort((seq1, seq2) => seq1.Sum() > seq2.Sum() ? -1 : (seq1.Sum() == seq2.Sum() ? 0 : 1));

        foreach (string res in sequences.Select(s => s.Aggregate("", (current, number) => current + (" " + number)))) {
            Console.WriteLine(res.Substring(1));
        }
        Console.ReadKey();
    }
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic
